page.title: 20Language, Stallingborough
page.content: Over recent years the village has become less rural in character and travel and communications have improved. With these changes language has become more uniform. The dialect (Lincolnshire) is now less commonly used, though older folk, and country people still lapse into it when speaking together. Some words are: Yock it on/off=couple. Cawker=very big Slaape=slippery. Onny middlin=not very well. Tates=potatoes. Swath=bacon rind Back end=autumn. Yawp=to sing Bub=unfledged bird. Tonnup=turnip. Arrerd=tired out. Kelcher=large one. Uneppen=clumsy. Puthering, siling = pouring with rain. Megger=improve in health. Fow-weltered =(sheep)on its back and unable to get up. Upskittle=knock over. Skell Ower=fall over.
